(Outer shafts) |Ship speed=20 knots |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship capacity= |Ship complement=19 |Ship armament=*1 × 40 mm anti-aircraft gun *2 × 20 mm anti aircraft guns |Ship armour= |Ship notes= }} |}
'''HMS ''Beckford'' (P3104)''' was one of 20 [[Ford class seaward defence boat|Ford-class]] [[patrol boat]]s built for the [[Royal Navy]] in the 1950s.<ref>Colledge, J. J.; Warlow, Ben (2006) [1969]. Ships of the Royal Navy: The Complete Record of all Fighting Ships of the Royal Navy (Rev. ed.). London: Chatham Publishing. ISBN 978-1-86176-281-8. OCLC 67375475</ref>
Their names were all chosen from villages ending in ''[[Ford (crossing)|-ford]]''. This boat was named after [[Beckford, Worcestershire]].
''Beckford'' was launched on 27 April 55. She was later renamed '''HMS ''Dee''''' whilst serving as the training tender to the Mersey Division of the Royal Naval Reserve. <ref>Blackman, Raymond V. B. ''Jane's Fighting Ships 1971–72''. London: Sampson Low, Marston & Company, 1971. ISBN 0-354-00096-9</ref><ref name="shipspotting"/> In 1968 the vessel was chartered by the [[Plessey|Plessey Group]] and renamed ''Robert Clive'', then returned as HMS ''Dee'' to the RNR in January 1969. She was placed on the disposals list in 1982 and sold to Pounds Marine Shipping in 1984 <ref name="shipspotting"/> She was fitted with [[schooner]] rig and (as of 2014) has been anchored off [[Shotley, Suffolk]]<ref name="Ghosting"/> in [[Harwich]] harbour for "a very long time."<ref name="shipspotting">''[http://www.shipspotting.com/gallery/photo.php?lid=262791 Beckford]'' page on shipspotting.com website, viewed 2012-12-09</ref>
==In popular culture== ===HMS ''Beckfoot''===
''Beckford'' was an inspiration for the fictional vessel HMS ''Beckfoot'' (also called ''[[HMS Hispaniola|Hispaniola]]'' and ''Pride of Macau'') in the [[Strong Winds trilogy]] of children's books by [[Julia Jones (writer)|Julia Jones]].<ref name="Ghosting">Author's endnote, [[Julia Jones (writer)|Julia Jones]], ''Ghosting Home'' (Strong Winds Trilogy 3) ISBN 978-1899262069 July 2, 2012</ref>
==References== [[File:Strong_Winds_trilogy.png|thumb|left|HMS ''Beckford'' features on the cover of ''[[Strong Winds trilogy|Ghosting Home]]'' (right), a children's adventure novel]] <references/>
